results.headline: Hey, Kids, Is Everybody Up for Some Guerrilla Warfare?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Daddy Day Camp

results.summary_short: “Daddy Day Camp” is a recruiting poster for kids, insisting that there’s no domestic problem that military values can’t solve.

results.headline: He’s Still No Seer, but Underdog Is Here

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Underdog

results.summary_short: A motherless boy, a graceless dog and a witless script propel “Underdog,” a live-action resurrection of the 1960s television series.

results.headline: Bollywood Goes on a Trip to the A.T.M.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cash

results.summary_short: “Cash,” a Bollywood caper, provides abundant proof that Hollywood pictures have no monopoly on ostentatious wealth, or, to use a spent expression, bling.

results.headline: A Little Girl in the Eye of Her Family’s Political Storms

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blame It on Fidel

results.summary_short: Julie Gavras’s wonderful film, “Blame It on Fidel,” views its ideological conflicts through the eyes of a smart, willful child.

results.headline: Life, Assembled One Room at a Time

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Colossal Youth

results.summary_short: Beautifully photographed, the elliptical, often mysterious and wholly beguiling film “Colossal Youth” looks and sounds as if it were made on another planet.

results.headline: Still Searching, but With Darker Eyes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bourne Ultimatum

results.summary_short: For Jason Bourne, who rises and rises again in this fantastically kinetic, propulsive film, resurrection is the name of the game, just as it is for franchises.

results.headline: Blind Man’s Dark Paradise, Laid to Waste by the Gift of Sight

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Willow Tree

results.summary_short: “The Willow Tree” examines the traumatic shocks experienced by a blind professor of literature whose eyesight is miraculously restored.

results.headline: The Profane Before the Sacred

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ten

results.summary_short: With “The Ten,” David Wain uses the Ten Commandments the way a suicide uses a bridge.

results.headline: Our Wit-Lit Heroine Avoids Marrying a Juiceless Man

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Becoming Jane

results.summary_short: “Becoming Jane” is an imitation screen adaptation of an Austen-like novel that imagines the author’s romantic life at 20.

results.headline: Never Pick a Fight With a Washing Machine

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hot Rod

results.summary_short: “Hot Rod” might be called the poor man’s “Eagle vs. Shark.” Poor certainly describes the quality of the filmmaking.

results.headline: Big Money, Big Houses and Big, Nasty Demons

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of If I Didn't Care

results.summary_short: “If I Didn’t Care,” a noir set in the Hamptons, stokes the tempting fantasy that this elite enclave on the southeastern shore of Long Island is the seat of all evil.

results.headline: When the Salsa Throbs, a Singer’s Soul Is Revealed

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of El Cantante

results.summary_short: Whenever Marc Anthony takes the stage as Héctor Lavoe in “El Cantante,” he unleashes his charisma and shows that, whatever his limitations as an actor, he is a brilliant performer.

results.headline: Tender Hearts and Lip-Gloss Dreams

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bratz: The Movie

results.summary_short: Arriving as inevitably as puberty, “Bratz” introduces the swollen-headed, fashion-addicted dolls of the title to a live-action movie.

results.headline: A Drowsy Family Vacation, Except for That Little Affair

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Summer '04

results.summary_short: “Summer ’04” is so plainly the product of meticulous forethought that the shooting script might have been etched on marble slabs.

results.headline: Plight of Muslim Immigrants in Post-Sept. 11 America

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Out of Status

results.summary_short: In their no-frills documentary, “Out of Status,” Pia Sawhney and Sanjna N. Singh examine the actions of the Immigration and Naturalization Service after 9/11.

results.headline: Lindsay Lohan’s New Role: I’m Not Who They Think I Am

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Know Who Killed Me

results.summary_short: Pretentious and inane, “I Know Who Killed Me” arouses unexpected sympathy for its embattled star.

results.headline: Storming the Country Club in a Helicopter

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Who's Your Caddy?

results.summary_short: There’s probably more wit and pointed social commentary in the average four-minute OutKast song than in the entirety of “Who’s Your Caddy?”

results.headline: We’ll Always Have Springfield

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Simpsons Movie

results.summary_short: “The Simpsons Movie” is full of the anarchic, generous, good-natured humor that is the show’s enduring signature.

results.headline: In the Beginning: Focusing on the Iraq War Enablers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No End in Sight

results.summary_short: “No End in Sight” offers an emphatic, well- supported answer to a question that has already begun to be mooted on television talk shows: Who lost Iraq?

results.headline: In Thatcher’s Britain, a Fellowship of the Skins

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This is England

results.summary_short: A modest, near-flawless gem, “This Is England” is a humbly, if insistently political, autobiographical homage to a lost world of youth.
